tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Why are the nations in turmoil ... why do the peoples make plots that will fail?
tn.text: These two clauses have similar meanings, and the "nations" and "peoples" refer to the same group of people. The words "nations" and "peoples" may represent their rulers. AT: "Why are the leaders of the nations in turmoil and making plots that will fail?" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Why are the nations in turmoil, and why do the peoples make plots that will fail?
tn.text: These questions are used to show surprise that the people are doing something so wrong and foolish. AT: "The nations are in turmoil and the peoples are making plots that will fail." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This probably means that the nations were making a noisy and angry commotion.
These are probably plots against God and his people.

tn.ref: The kings of the earth take their stand together ... the rulers conspire together
tn.text: These two clauses have similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"gather to fight" or "unite and prepare to revolt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Let us tear off the shackles ... throw off their chains
tn.text: The people of other nations speak of Yahweh and the Messiah's rule over them as if it were shackles and chains.  AT: "We should free ourselves from their control; we should not let them rule over us any longer!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These phrases refer to Yahweh. Yahweh is often called "the Lord" but the words for "Yahweh" and "the Lord" are different.

Here sitting represents ruling. What he sits on can be stated clearly. AT: "rules in the heavens" or "sits on his throne in heaven" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"the Lord mocks those people." Why he mocks them can be stated clearly. AT: "The Lord mocks them for their foolish plans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: and terrify them in his rage
tn.text: "rage" can be refers to being extremely angry or being furious. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"frighten"
Yahweh is emphasizing that he, and not someone else, has anointed his king.
"appointed my king to rule"

tn.ref: I will announce a decree of Yahweh
tn.text: The person saying this is the king. This can be stated clearly. AT: "The king says 'I will announce a decree of Yahweh'"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Yahweh said to me"

tn.ref: You are my son! This day I have become your father
tn.text: Among many peoples in that part of the world then, men could decide to legally adopt children, who would become their heirs. Here Yahweh adopts a man and makes him king of Israel. AT: "I make you my son. This day I have become your father" or "Now you are my son and am your father"
Yahweh continues speaking to the new king of Israel.

tn.ref: the nations for your inheritance ... the farthermost regions of the earth for your possession
tn.text: These phrases express very similar ideas.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: the farthermost regions of the earth
tn.text: "the lands that are very far away"

tn.ref: You will break them with an iron rod; like a jar of a potter, you will smash them to pieces
tn.text: These phrases express very similar ideas.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: You will break them with an iron rod
tn.text: Defeating the nations is spoken of as breaking them, and his power is spoken of as an iron rod. AT: "You will defeat them completely by your power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you will smash them to pieces
tn.text: Destroying nations is spoken of as if they could be smashed like a clay jar. AT: you will completely destroy them like a clay pot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
A potter is a person who makes clay pots and jars. These are fragile and can be broken easily. AT: "a clay jar" or "a clay pot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: So now, you kings, be warned; be corrected, you rulers of the earth
tn.text: These two phrases have similar meanings. AT: "So now, you kings and rulers of the earth, be warned and corrected" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This can be stated with an active form. AT: "listen to this warning" or "be wise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated with an active form. AT: "listen to this correction" or "take this correction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

People would show their king that they were loyal to him by kissing him, perhaps on the feet. AT: "Show the son that you are truly loyal to him" or "Bow down humbly before his son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: you will die in the way
tn.text: This may refer to dying right there, before the person has a chance to go away. AT: "you will die immediately"

tn.ref: when his anger burns for just a moment
tn.text: The king's anger is spoken of as if it were a fire that could burn. AT: "when he suddenly becomes very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Asking the king for protection is spoken of as seeking refuge in him. AT: "ask the king to protect them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
